rules.title: Definite Articles (der, die, das)
rules.description: German has three definite articles that correspond to the three grammatical genders: masculine (der), feminine (die), and neuter (das).
rules.notes: The article 'die' is also used for all plural nouns regardless of gender.

rules.title: Indefinite Articles (ein, eine)
rules.description: Indefinite articles are used for non-specific nouns. 'Ein' is used for masculine and neuter, 'eine' for feminine.
rules.notes: There is no plural form of the indefinite article in German.

rules.title: Present Tense - Regular Verbs
rules.description: Regular verbs follow a predictable pattern in the present tense. Remove '-en' from the infinitive and add the appropriate ending.
rules.notes: The stem remains the same throughout all conjugations.

rules.title: Present Tense - sein (to be)
rules.description: The verb 'sein' is irregular and must be memorized.
rules.notes: This is one of the most important verbs in German and is highly irregular.

rules.title: Present Tense - haben (to have)
rules.description: The verb 'haben' is irregular in some forms.
rules.notes: Notice the irregular forms 'hast' and 'hat'.

rules.title: Basic Word Order (SVO)
rules.description: In simple German sentences, the word order follows Subject-Verb-Object pattern.
rules.notes: The verb is always in second position in a main clause.

rules.title: Nominative Case
rules.description: The nominative case is used for the subject of the sentence and after the verb 'sein'.
examples: Der Mann ist groß. (The man is tall.)
Das Buch ist neu. (The book is new.)
rules.notes: This is the 'default' case and the one you find in the dictionary.

rules.title: Accusative Case
rules.description: The accusative case is used for the direct object of the sentence. Only masculine articles change (der → den, ein → einen).
examples: Ich sehe den Mann. (I see the man.)
Er hat einen Hund. (He has a dog.)
Sie kauft das Buch. (She buys the book.)
rules.notes: Feminine, neuter, and plural articles remain the same as in nominative.

rules.title: Personal Pronouns
rules.description: German personal pronouns in nominative case.
rules.notes: Note the capitalization of 'Sie' (formal you) even in the middle of sentences.

rules.title: Numbers 1-20
rules.description: Basic numbers from one to twenty.
rules.notes: Numbers 13-19 follow the pattern: number + zehn (e.g., drei + zehn = dreizehn).

rules.title: Negation with 'nicht'
rules.description: 'Nicht' is used to negate verbs, adjectives, or entire sentences.
examples: Das ist nicht gut. (That is not good.)
Er kommt nicht. (He is not coming.)
rules.notes: 'Nicht' usually comes after the verb or at the end of the sentence.

rules.title: Negation with 'kein'
rules.description: 'Kein' is used to negate nouns and replaces the indefinite article.
examples: Ich habe kein Geld. (I have no money.)
Das ist keine gute Idee. (That is not a good idea.)
Sie hat keinen Hund. (She has no dog.)
rules.notes: 'Kein' follows the same declension pattern as 'ein'.

rules.title: Yes/No Questions
rules.description: To form yes/no questions, place the verb first, followed by the subject.
examples: Ist das dein Buch? (Is that your book?)
Hast du Zeit? (Do you have time?)
Lernt sie Deutsch? (Is she learning German?)
rules.notes: The verb moves to first position. Answer with 'Ja' (yes) or 'Nein' (no).

rules.title: W-Questions (Question Words)
rules.description: W-questions begin with a question word, followed by the verb.
examples: Was machst du? (What are you doing?)
Wo wohnst du? (Where do you live?)
Wann kommst du? (When are you coming?)
Wie heißt du? (What is your name?)
Warum lernst du Deutsch? (Why are you learning German?)
rules.notes: Common question words: wer (who), was (what), wo (where), wann (when), wie (how), warum (why).

rules.title: Plural Formation
rules.description: German nouns form plurals in various ways. There are five main plural patterns.
examples: die Mutter → die Mütter (mother/mothers) - add umlaut
der Lehrer → die Lehrer (teacher/teachers) - no change
rules.notes: Plural forms must be learned with each noun. All plural nouns use 'die' as the article.

rules.title: Basic Adjectives (Predicative)
rules.description: When adjectives come after the verb 'sein', they don't take endings.
examples: Der Mann ist groß. (The man is tall.)
Die Frau ist nett. (The woman is nice.)
Das Haus ist klein. (The house is small.)
Die Kinder sind glücklich. (The children are happy.)
rules.notes: This is the easiest way to use adjectives. No endings needed!

rules.title: Possessives: mein, dein
rules.description: Basic possessive pronouns for 'my' and 'your' (informal).
rules.notes: Possessives follow the same pattern as 'ein/eine'. 'Mein' for masculine/neuter, 'meine' for feminine.

rules.title: Prepositions: in, aus
rules.description: Basic prepositions for location and origin.
examples: Ich wohne in Berlin. (I live in Berlin.)
Sie arbeitet in Deutschland. (She works in Germany.)
Er kommt aus Italien. (He comes from Italy.)
Wir kommen aus der Schweiz. (We come from Switzerland.)
rules.notes: 'In' indicates location, 'aus' indicates origin. Both take dative case (at A1, use them with place names).

rules.title: Days of the Week
rules.description: The seven days of the week in German.
rules.notes: All days are masculine (der Montag). Use 'am' for 'on': am Montag (on Monday).

rules.title: Months of the Year
rules.description: The twelve months in German.
rules.notes: All months are masculine (der Januar). Use 'im' for 'in': im Mai (in May).

rules.title: Common Greetings
rules.description: Essential greetings and farewells for everyday situations.
rules.notes: Use 'Guten Morgen' until about 11 am, 'Guten Tag' during the day, 'Guten Abend' from about 6 pm.

rules.title: Numbers 20-100
rules.description: Counting by tens and forming compound numbers.
rules.notes: Compound numbers are written as one word, with the ones digit first: einundzwanzig (one-and-twenty).

rules.title: Telling Time (Basic)
rules.description: Basic time expressions for telling the hour.
examples: Wie spät ist es? / Wie viel Uhr ist es? (What time is it?)
Es ist ein Uhr. (It's one o'clock.)
Es ist drei Uhr. (It's three o'clock.)
Es ist zehn Uhr. (It's ten o'clock.)
rules.notes: Use 'ein Uhr' for 1 o'clock. For other hours, use the number + Uhr.

rules.title: The Verb 'möchten' (would like)
rules.description: A polite way to express wishes and desires.
rules.notes: Very useful for ordering in restaurants or shopping: 'Ich möchte einen Kaffee.' (I would like a coffee.)

rules.title: Common Regular Verbs
rules.description: Essential regular verbs for daily conversation.
rules.notes: These verbs follow regular conjugation patterns. Practice with different subjects.

rules.title: Courtesy Phrases
rules.description: Polite expressions for daily interactions.
examples: Wie bitte? (Pardon? / What did you say?)
rules.notes: 'Bitte' is very versatile - it means both 'please' and 'you're welcome'.
